title: How Trey Flowers, Lions' $90 million man, finally came up money against Giants
text:
CLOSE

The $90 million man finally produced for the Detroit Lions — and it couldn’t have come at a better time.

Trey Flowers, the defensive end who signed a five-year deal worth up to $90 million in free agency, had a pair of sacks in the Lions’ 31-26 victory over the New York Giants.

“Me? I just want to create big plays for my teammates and put them in a position to win,” Flowers said.

And that’s exactly what he did.

Flowers came into the game with just one sack before he simply overpowered Giants left tackle Nate Solder.

There are two ways to look at that:

Flowers did what was expected against Solder.

It would be worse, and more eye-popping, if Flowers didn’t produce some pressure against Solder, who had allowed 26 quarterback pressures and five sacks in his first seven games this season, according to Pro Football Focus.

So the sacks were there for the taking — they always are against Solder — and Flowers produced. Finally.

“It’s a testament to the defense on those plays that allowed me to be able to get back there,” Flowers said. “I just made the play when it came to me.”

His sacks came on successive plays at a crucial time in the fourth quarter when the Lions were holding onto a 31-19 lead. Keen observers know this about the Lions: No lead is safe.

The Giants advanced to the Detroit 43-yard line, but Flowers recorded back-to-back sacks to end the drive.

“There were some pretty big plays out there, pretty big moments,” Lions coach Matt Patricia said. “And I thought — we always talk about trying to stay in the moment — not thinking about what’s the next thing, what’s going to happen and do all of that. I thought the guys did a good job of that. That’s the biggest thing for us, just play that play in that moment, and for the most part I thought we were pretty good.”

Sack artist

A sack is an individual stat, but it’s also an indication that other defensive players are doing their jobs.

First, the defensive line has to keep the quarterback in the pocket. The defensive backs have to hold coverage, forcing the quarterback to wait a split second.

And the rusher has to make a move to get free.

"Collectively, as a team, guys make them hold the ball, guys keep him in the pocket," Flowers said. "A lot goes with a sack. Obviously, to get home and create a big play feels good.”

Flowers showed off two different moves to bring down Giants quarterback Daniel Jones.

On his first sack, Flowers started off with a bull rush and grabbed Solder and threw him to the side.

“On the first one, I snatched,” Flowers said.

Yes, more snatching. That’s what the Lions need.

“That’s the same thing I did at Green Bay,” he said.

“The ones where you got called for grabbing his face?” I asked.

“That’s how it goes,” he said, smiling.

On his second sack, Flowers started off with a bull rush.

But instead of doing a snatch, he simply continued on a bull rush.

“On the second one, I continued to push him back," Flowers said. "A bull rush.”

Boom. Down goes Jones.

Finally, some pressure

Jones had all kinds of time against the Lions in the first half. The Lions didn’t record a quarterback hit and Jones completed 12 of 16 passes. But the Lions dialed up more pressure in the second half.

“We made a lot of adjustments and a lot of corrections in the game that we were trying to make, and changed some stuff up mid-way to do the best we could to hang in,” Patricia said. “Give the players credit, I thought they tried really hard, and like I said, I think that’s a good team there — the Giants.”

The Lions finished the day with five quarterback hits.

Finally, they started to get some pressure on a quarterback.

“It’s never really perfect,” Patricia said. "We just try to be right, and the more we can be right together, then the better off we’re going to be. (I’m) really proud of some of the effort out there, I thought it was really good. I’m always proud of those guys the way they work to be honest with you."

In the end, the Lions won a game they had to win.

They finally got some pressure on the quarterback.

And the defense made some huge plays.

If only they could play the Giants every week.

description: The Detroit Lions signed Trey Flowers to a deal worth up to $90 million in the offseason. Yet until Sunday, Flowers had unperformed.
